Section.Description: This section summarizes the environmental fate/exposure of this chemical, including the natural and artificial sources of the chemical as a pollutant, its environmental fate, biodegradation, abiotic degradation, bioconcentration, etc.

StringWithMarkup.String: Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether's production and use in hydraulic fluids, industrial solvents, vinyl and acrylic paints, household cleaners, and as a solvent in cosmetics may result in its release to the environment through various waste streams. Its use as a product stabilizer in hydraulic fracturing fluids for gas well drilling and as an oil slick dispersant will result in its direct release to the environment. If released to air, a vapor pressure of 0.88 mm Hg at 25 °C indicates ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether will exist solely as a vapor in the ambient atmosphere. Vapor-phase ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether will be degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals; the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 15 hours. Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether does not contain chromophores that absorb at wavelengths >290 nm, and therefore is not expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight. If released to soil, ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is expected to have high mobility based upon an estimated Koc of 8. Volatilization from moist soil surfaces is expected to be an important fate process based upon a Henry's Law constant of 1.60X10-6 atm-cu m/mole. If released into water, ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is not expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment based upon the estimated Koc. Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether reached 96% of its Theoretical BOD in 14 days using an activated sludge inoculum. Therefore this compound has the potential to biodegrade rapidly in water. Volatilization from water surfaces is expected to be an important fate process based upon this compound's estimated Henry's Law constant. The estimated volatilization half-lives for a model river and model lake are 17 and 185 days, respectively. An estimated BCF of 3 suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low. Hydrolysis is not expected to be an important environmental fate process since this compound lacks functional groups that hydrolyze under environmental conditions. Occupational exposure to ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food or contaminated drinking water, and dermal contact with this compound or consumer products containing this compound particularly during the use of paints/varnishes, cleaning solutions, or cosmetics. (SRC)

StringWithMarkup.String: Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether's production and use in hydraulic fluids(1), as coupling agent for many water-based coatings(2), industrial solvents(3), vinyl and acrylic paints(4), household cleaners(2), and as a solvent in cosmetics(5) may result in its release to the environment through various waste streams(SRC). Its use as a product stabilizer in hydraulic fracturing fluids for gas well drilling(6,7) and as an oil slick dispersant(8) will result in its direct release to the environment(SRC).

Section.Description: Environmental fate describes where this chemical goes when it gets out into the environment and how it might be chemically transformed in that process.  This section may provide information on multiple types of environmental fates of the chemical (e.g., aquatic fate, terrestrial fate, and atmospheric fate).

Reference: (1) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(2) Hansch C et al; Exploring QSAR. Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. ACS Prof Ref Book. Heller SR, consult. ed., Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc p. 25 (1995)

(4) Dow Chemical Company; The Glycol Ethers Handbook. Midland, MI: The Dow Chemical Company pp. 97 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: TERRESTRIAL FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), an estimated Koc value of 8(SRC), determined from a log Kow of 0.83(2), indicates that ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is expected to have very high mobility in soil(SRC). Volatilization of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether from moist soil surfaces is expected to be an important fate process(SRC) given an Henry's Law constant of 1.60X10-6 atm-cu m/mole(3). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is expected to volatilize slowly from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon a vapor pressure of 0.88 mm Hg(4). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether reached 96% of its theoretical BOD in 14 days using an activated sludge inoculum(5). Therefore this compound is expected to biodegrade rapidly in the soil environment.

Reference: (1) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(2) Hansch C et al; Exploring QSAR. Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. ACS Prof Ref Book. Heller SR, consult. ed., Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc p. 25 (1995)
(3) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 4-9, 15-1 to 15-29 (1990)
(4) Johanson G, Dynesius B; Brit J Indust Med 45: 561-564 (1988)
(5) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
(6) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.1. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Sept 23, 2011: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm
(7) Silverstein RM, Bassler GC; Spectrometric Id Org Cmpd. New York, NY: J Wiley and Sons Inc p. 148-169 (1963)

(8) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of Sept 26, 2011: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), an estimated Koc value of 8(SRC), determined from a log Kow of 0.83(2), indicates that ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is not expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment(SRC). Volatilization from water surfaces is expected(3) based upon a Henry's Law constant of 1.6X10-6 atm-cu m/mole(4). Using this Henry's Law constant and an estimation method(3), volatilization half-lives for a model river and model lake are 17 and 185 days, respectively(SRC). According to a classification scheme(5), an estimated BCF of 3, from its log Kow of 0.83(2) and a regression-derived equation(6), suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC). Alcohols and ethers are generally resistant to hydrolysis(7). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether reached 96% of its Theoretical BOD in 14 days using an activated sludge inoculum(8). Therefore this compound is expected to biodegrade rapidly in the aquatic environment.

Reference: (1) Bidleman TF; Environ Sci Technol 22: 361-367 (1988)
(2) Dow Chemical Company; The Glycol Ethers Handbook. The Dow Chemical Company, Midland, MI 97 pp (1990)
(3) Atkinson R; J Phys Chem Ref Data. Monograph No 1 (1989)
(4) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 8-12 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether, which has a vapor pressure of 0.88 mm Hg at 25 °C(2) is expected to exist solely as a vapor in the ambient atmosphere. Vapor-phase ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 15 hours(SRC), calculated from its rate constant of 1.86X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(3). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether does not contain chromophores that absorb at wavelengths >290 nm(4), and therefore is not expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) Bridie AL et al; Water Res 13: 627-30 (1979)
(2) Price KS et al; J Water Pollut Contr Fed 46: 63-77 (1974)
(3) Sasaki S; pp. 283-98 in Aquat Pollutants: Transform & Biolog Effects. Hutzinger O et al, eds., Oxf: Pergamon Press (1978)
(4) Takemoto S et al; Suishitsu Odaku Kenkyu 4: 80-90 (1981)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: A number of aerobic biological screening studies, which utilized settled waste water, sewage, or activated sludge for inocula, indicate that ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether should biodegrade rapidly in the environment(1-4). Five and ten-day Theoretical BOD values were 73% (with acclimation)(1) and 74%(2). The maximum Theoretical BOD reported was 88% for 20 days(2).

Reference: (1) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of Sept 26, 2011: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html
(2) Staples CA et al; Chemosphere 36: 1585-1613 (1998)
(3) Dow Chemical Company; The Glycol Ethers Handbook. Midland, MI: The Dow Chemical Company pp. 97 (1990)
(4) Waggy GT et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 13: 1277-80 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether, present at 100 mg/L in an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L, achieved 96% Theoretical biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)and 96% total organic carbon (TOC) for biodegradation under a modified MITI test, OECD 301C, and was classified as readily biodegradable(1). Therefore this compound is expected to biodegrade rapidly. Biodegradation tests of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether with adapted domestic sewage (in fresh and salt water) or non-adapted domestic activated sludge under aerobic conditions show that 75% to 100% of the chemical was removed after 20 to 28 days(2). The Theoretical BODs for ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether after 5, 10, and 20 days have been determined to be 5, 57, and 72%(3). Biooxidation of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether using a 20 day BOD test and a 28 day OECD test resulted in 88 and 75% degradation(4).

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) Atkinson R; J Phys Chem Ref Data. p. 141 (1989)
(2) Meylan WM, Howard PH; Chemosphere 26: 2293-99 (1993)
(3) Silverstein RM, Bassler GC; Spectrometric Id Org Cmpd. New York, NY: John Wiley and Sons Inc p. 148-169 (1963)
(4) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 7-4, 7-5, 8-12 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals is 1.86X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 15 hours at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(2). Alcohols and ethers are generally resistant to hydrolysis(3). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is not expected to undergo hydrolysis in the environment due to the lack of hydrolyzable functional groups(4).Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether does not contain chromophores that absorb at wavelengths >290 nm(4), and therefore is not expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC).

Reference: (1) US EPA; EPA Region 8. Superfund. Wyoming Cleanup Sites. Groundwater Investigation, Pavillion, WY, EPA ID WYN00080273. Wasshington, DC: US EPA. Available from, as of Sept 23, 2011: https://www.epa.gov/region8/superfund/wy/pavillion/

StringWithMarkup.String: In a study of groundwater sampled from private wells in the vicinity of a natural gas drilling well in Pavillion, Wyoming ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was not analyzed. However, 2-butoxyethanol phosphate, which can be formed by the reaction of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether with naturally occurring phosphates, was detected in 9 of 17 wells at levels of 0.55-2.10 ug/L and was not a constituent in the EPA list of drilling fluid compounds(1).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) Hansch C et al; Exploring QSAR. Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. ACS Prof Ref Book. Heller SR, consult. ed., Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc p.25 (1995)

StringWithMarkup.String: An estimated BCF of 3 was calculated for ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether(SRC), using an estimated log Kow of 0.83(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Hansch C et al; Exploring QSAR. Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. ACS Prof Ref Book. Heller SR, consult. ed., Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc p. 25 (1995)
(2) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.1. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Sept 23, 2011: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm
(3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)

According to a classification scheme(3), this estimated Koc value suggests that ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is expected to have high mobility in soil.

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is 1.6X10-6 atm-cu m/mole(1). This Henry's Law constant indicates that ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether may volatilize from water surfaces(2). Based on this Henry's Law constant, the volatilization half-life from a model river (1 m deep, flowing 1 m/sec, wind velocity of 3 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 17 days(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model lake (1 m deep, flowing 0.05 m/sec, wind velocity of 0.5 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 185 days(SRC). The Henry's law constant of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces may occur(SRC). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon a vapor pressure of 0.88 mm Hg(3).

However, ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected from the heavily polluted Hayashida River in Japan. The range was 1.31 to 5.68 mg/L(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR: Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in some indoor air samples collected in five buildings in rural, suburban, or city environments in Greece(1). The concentration detected in one building was approximately 4 micrograms/cu m(1). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was not detected or was present at very low concentrations in the other four buildings tested(1). Data compiled from a large number of sources in the U.S., representing 30 cities in 16 states, indicates that ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in indoor environments (not including industrial indoor air) at average and median concentrations of 0.214 and 0.075 ppbv, respectively(2). The maximum air concentrations of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether in four manufactured and seven site-built houses in Florida (U.S.) were 5.8 and 12.3 ppb, respectively(3). Low levels of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether were detected in indoor air of offices in commercial buildings in several states in the US(4). This survey examined indoor VOC concentrations in telecommunications buildings, administrative offices, and data centers(4). The reported geometric means in these indoor environments ranged from 0.1 to 1.0 micrograms/cu m. However, these values were affected by the high number of samples with levels below the detection limit (reported to be 0.050 micrograms/cu m)(4). The highest and second highest values detected in the survey ranged from 16 to 33 micrograms/cu m and 5 to 17 micrograms/cu m, respectively(4).

Reference: (1) Soehnlein B et al; Int Arch Occup Environ Health 64: 479-84 (1993)
(2) Stefaniak AB et al; Environ Res 83: 162-73 (2000)
(3) Vincent R et al; Appl Occup Environ Hyg 8: 580-6 (1993)

(5) Winder C, Turner PJ; Ann Occup Hyg 36: 261-8 (1992)
(6) Zhu J et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 3964-3971 (2005)

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR: Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in the breathing zone of workers involved in varnish production(1). The mean concentrations on two consecutive days were 0.5 and 0.6 ppm with a maximum concentration of 1.4 ppm(1). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in air samples collected in two of three copy centers in the US(2). Mean concentrations of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether were 5.3 and 64.4 ppb(2). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was not detected in one of the two sampling days(2). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in air samples taken in the breathing zone of office and car cleaners using cleaning solutions that contained ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether. Mean concentrations in the breathing zone of car cleaners ranged from 0.45 to 4.89 ppm. Concentrations in the breathing zone of office cleaners did not exceed 0.73 ppm and had a mean of 0.32 ppm(3). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in buildings with a history of occupant complaints. Average concentrations detected during a series of sampling events at different locations in the buildings ranged from 1.8 micrograms/cu m to 34 micrograms/cu m(4). A study of the spray painting operations of 46 automotive repair shops in Australia showed that ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether concentrations in air ranged from 1,000 to 3,000 micrograms/cu m with a mean of 2,000 micrograms/cu m(5). In another study during the winter of 2002-2003 ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in 40 of 74 residential homes in Ottawa, Canada at concentrations ranging from 0.14 to 3.91 ug/cu m(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected at 99.2 micrograms/kg (99.2 ppb) in one of three samples of fermented soybean curds collected from a Hong Kong market(1). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in raw but not roasted earth-almonds (Cyperus esculentus L.) collected in Valencia, Spain(2). The detected concentrations were not presented(2). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected as it was released from frankfurters (50 g samples) during steam distillation(3). The amount of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether that was released varied among frankfurters with different fat contents, although not linearly(3). Relative chromatographic peak areas, not concentrations, were presented(3). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in raw beef extracted by supercritical fluid extraction with carbon dioxide(4). The ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in a volatile fraction and none was detected in the condensed, lipid fraction(4). Relative chromatographic peak areas, not concentrations, were presented(4). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was detected in cooked mussels collected in France(5). The concentrations of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether detected in tissue or volatile fraction emitted by the mussels were not reported(5).

A paint stripping formulation was comprised of 35% ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether(3). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was not detected in a machine cutting fluid prior to its use; however, the used fluid contained ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether at a concn of 0.060 ug/g(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was qualitatively detected in the headspace of liquid wax for marble, ceramic, linoleum, plastic, and varnished wood floors(1). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was found in printer's inks used for serigraphy on paper and paper boards at concentrations of 0.1 and 0.4 wt%, respectively(2). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether has been identified as a major component of latex caulk(3). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether has been identified in a variety of household products including paints, primers and varnishes; all purpose cleaners; window and glass cleaners; engine degreasers; rug and upholstery cleaners; and metal cleaners and polishes(4). Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether emission rates for 6 varnished parquets were determined to be 6 and 5 ug/sq m-hr at 3 days and 4 weeks old, respectively(5). Emissions rates of 100-3000 mg/sq m-hr were determined for 20 consumer products including wood surface treating stains, general cleaning agents, and degreasers(6).

Another study reported emission rates of a piece of furniture constructed from particle board (wood veneer) had an emission rate of 14,456 ug/cu m at day 1, and 40 ug/cu m at day 40(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 2,139,297 workers (585,932 of these are female) are potentially exposed to ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether in the US(1). Occupational exposure to ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether via inhalation of ambient air and dermal contact with this compound or consumer products containing this compound particularly during the use of paints/varnishes, cleaning solutions, or cosmetics(SRC). Workplace exposures have been documented in detail(2-6).

StringWithMarkup.String: According to the National Ambient Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) Database, the median workplace atmospheric concentration of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is 0.075 ppbV for 14 samples(1). A study conducted in 1989 of 1448 Danish businesses comprising 19 industrial categories showed that there were an estimated 55,000 events with potential occupational exposure to ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether(2). Approximately 37% of these potential exposures occurred in manufacture of fabricated metal products(2). In another study, breathing zone concentrations of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether that exceeded the NIOSH recommended exposure limit of 24 mg/cu m were reported in workers performing asbestos removal at Ohio University, Athens, Ohio(3). Personal exposures to atmospheric ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether at a specialty chemical production facility in June of 1981 ranged from undetected levels to 0.1 ppm; indoor air concentrations within the facility were as high as 1.7 ppm(4). A national survey of workplaces in the Federal Republic of Germany showed that workers were exposed to solvents containing ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether with a 0.4% frequency of occurrence(5). At a varnish production facility the concentration of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether in air was <0.1-1.4 ppm with a mean of 0.6 ppm(6). Several other comprehensive reviews report concentrations of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl in air at manufacturing/formulation facilities that range from <0.1-9.7 ppm(7), <0.1-44.7 ppm(8), and <0.2-63 ppm (9).

Reference: (1) Yasuhara A et al; Agric Bio Chem 50: 1765-70 (1986)
(2) Lucas SV; GC/MS Anal of Org in Drinking Water Concentrates and Advanced Treatment Concentrates Vol 1 USEPA-600/1-84-020A (NTIS PB85-128239) p 397 (1984)
(3) Tichenor BA, Mason MA; JAPCA 38: 264-8 (1988)

StringWithMarkup.String: Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether was identified as a volatile emission from used machine cutting oils in an automobile manufacturing facility in Japan(1). Non-occupational exposures may occur among populations with contaminated drinking water supplies(2). Because ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether is a component of solvent based building materials such as silicone caulk(3), human exposures may occur at construction sites and areas that have undergone remodelling(SRC).

Although correlation of ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl in air and its major metabolite (2-butoxyacetic acid)in postshift urinary levels was poor, postshift total 2-butoxyacetic acid levels in urine on Monday and Friday were 446.8 and 619.4 mg/g creatinine, respectively(1).

The workers ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether concentration in urine(1). The average preshift and postshift urinary concentrations of 12 varnish production facility workers was 53.2 and 53.8 mg/L with a range of 2.3-180.0 and 11.1-143.7 mg/L, respectively. The population with the highest concentration was workers involved directly in varnish production(2).

Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.

Reference.Name: SID 403030740
Reference.Description: The PATENTSCOPE database from WIPO includes patent and chemical structure search (with a free account) that gives access to millions of patent documents. The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) is a specialized United Nations (UN) agency headquartered in Geneva (Switzerland). Our mission is to lead the development of a balanced and effective international Intellectual Property (IP) system that enables innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. We help governments, businesses and society realize the benefits of Intellectual Property and are notably a world reference source for IP information.
